Package jblob.core

Interface Blob

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    Blob.Diff
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    ByteBlob, ByteBlob.Diff
    public interface Blob
    Represents an immutable binary blob of data representing a piece of content.. Blobs are immutable data structures which, when written, construct new blobs. Blobs are also elastic in that they automatically resize to accommodate writing beyond their current bounds.
    Author:
    David J. Pearce

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Interface Description
      static interface  Blob.Diff
      Replacements cannot overlap.
      static interface  Blob.Replacement

      Insert a given 32-bit signed integer byte to a given position within this blob assuming a big endian orientation.

        Returns:

        Returns:

      • readBytes

        byte[] readBytes​(int index,
                 int length)
        Read a given sequence of bytes from a given position in the blob. The entire region must be within bounds.
        Parameters:
        index -
        length -
        Returns:

      • readBytes

        void readBytes​(int index,
               int length,
               byte[] dest,
               int destStart)
        Read a given sequence of bytes from a given position in the blob into a prexisting array. The entire region must be within bounds.
        Parameters:
        index - The index within this blob to start reading from
        length - The number of bytes to read
        dest - The destination byte array
        destStart - starting position within destination

      • writeByte

        Blob.Diff writeByte​(int index,
                    byte b)
        Write a given byte to a given position within this value. The index does not need to be in bounds since blobs are elastic. Thus, writing beyond bounds increases the size of the blob accordingly.
        Parameters:
        index - Position to overwrite
        b - data byte to written
        Returns:

      • writeShort

        Blob.Diff writeShort​(int index,
                     short i16)
        Write a given 16-bit signed integer byte to a given position within this blob assuming a big endian orientation. The index does not need to be in bounds since blobs are elastic. Thus, writing beyond bounds increases the size of the blob accordingly.
        Parameters:
        index - Position to overwrite
        b - data byte to written
        Returns:

      • writeInt

        Blob.Diff writeInt​(int index,
                   int i32)
        Write a given 32-bit signed integer byte to a given position within this blob assuming a big endian orientation. The index does not need to be in bounds since blobs are elastic. Thus, writing beyond bounds increases the size of the blob accordingly.
        Parameters:
        index - Position to overwrite
        b - data byte to written
        Returns:

      • writeBytes

        Blob.Diff writeBytes​(int index,
                     byte... bytes)
        Replace a given section of this value with a new sequence of bytes. The index does not need to be in bounds since blobs are elastic. Thus, writing beyond bounds increases the size of the blob accordingly.
        Parameters:
        index - Position to overwrite
        b - data byte to written
        Returns:

      • replaceBytes

        Blob.Diff replaceBytes​(int index,
                       int length,
                       byte... bytes)
        Replace a given section of this value with a new sequence of bytes. The new byte sequence does not need to be the same length as the section replaced. The index does not need to be in bounds since blobs are elastic. Thus, writing beyond bounds increases the size of the blob accordingly.
        Parameters:
        index - starting offset of section being replaced
        length - size of section being replaced
        b - data byte to written
        Returns:

      • insertByte

        Blob.Diff insertByte​(int index,
                     byte b)
        Insert a given byte to a given position within this value. The index does not need to be in bounds since blobs are elastic. Thus, inserting beyond bounds increases the size of the blob accordingly.
        Parameters:
        index - Position to insert before
        b - data byte to written
        Returns:

      • insertShort

        Blob.Diff insertShort​(int index,
                      short i16)

        Parameters:
        index - Position to insert before
        b - data byte to written
        Returns:

        Parameters:

      • merge

        Blob merge​(Blob sibling)
        Merge two (disjoint) siblings together into one. For this to be valid, they must either: both have the same parent; or one is the immediate parent of the other.
        Parameters:
        parent -
        Returns:
